choices.text: Autosomal dominant Inheritance
Mitochondrial Inheritance
Autosomal recessive

questions.text: A newborn is brought in for evaluation immediately after delivery. The baby is stable with normal vital signs, but upon physical examination, a fluid-filled sac is observed on the baby's back. Based on the clinical presentation and the image provided, the condition is diagnosed as a neural tube defect. The concerned mother inquires about the underlying cause and the pattern of inheritance for this condition. What is the most appropriate response to provide?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multifactorial Inheritance

 

Option B:

 

Neural tube defects (NTDs) like spina bifida (which the described fluid-filled sac might represent) are best understood as multifactorial in origin. This means that both genetic and environmental factors play a role in their development. While there may be a genetic predisposition, factors such as maternal folic acid intake before conception and during pregnancy significantly influence the risk of NTDs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Autosomal dominant Inheritance:

 

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance implies that the trait or condition is caused by a dominant allele on one of the autosomal chromosomes (non-sex chromosomes).
  • In the context of neural tube defects, autosomal dominant inheritance is not a common mode of transmission for these conditions.

 

Option C. Mitochondrial Inheritance:

 

  • Mitochondrial inheritance involves the transmission of genetic traits through the mitochondria, which are structures outside the cell nucleus.
  • Neural tube defects are not typically associated with mitochondrial inheritance.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive:

 

  • Autosomal recessive inheritance occurs when a person inherits two copies of a recessive allele for a particular gene.
  • This mode of inheritance is not commonly associated with neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural tube defects (NTDs) are congenital malformations that occur during the development of the neural tube in the embryo. Examples of NTDs include conditions like spina bifida and anencephaly.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition Page No-4226.

choices.text: The diagnosis based on the imaging findings is Schizencephaly
Absence of gyri are noted in this condition
Hypoplasia of the optic nerve and microphthalmia can be noted in this condition
The diagnosis based on the imaging findings is Lissencephaly.

questions.text: A 12-month-old child is brought to the pediatric emergency department due to recurrent seizures. On examination, the child exhibits failure to thrive and severe developmental delay. To investigate further, a T1-weighted MRI is performed, revealing distinctive imaging findings. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the child’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The diagnosis based on the imaging findings is Schizencephaly.

 

Option A:

 

The clinical features and the imaging findings reveal the presence of Lissencephaly.

 

Here absence of cerebral sulci and the maldeveloped sylvian fissures are noted.

 

It is a result of faulty neuroblast migration and associated with enlarged lateral ventricles. These clinical features include

 

  • Failure to thrive
  • Microcephaly
  • Developmental delay and 
  • Severe generalized seizures

 

Ocular abnormalities are common, including hypoplasia of the optic nerve and microphthalmia. It can be associated with Miller-Dieker syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Absence of gyri are noted in this condition.

 

  • Both schizencephaly and lissencephaly can be associated with abnormal cortical development, leading to the absence of gyri.

 

Option C. Hypoplasia of the optic nerve and microphthalmia can be noted in this condition.

 

  • lissencephaly can be associated with other neurological and developmental abnormalities, including optic nerve hypoplasia and microphthalmia.

 

Option D. The diagnosis based on the imaging findings is Lissencephaly.

 

  • Lissencephaly, also known as smooth brain, is characterized by a lack of normal convolutions (gyri) in the cerebral cortex.

 

Educational objective:

 

Differentiating MRI features - Schizencephaly often presents with clefts in the cerebral hemispheres, while Lissencephaly is characterized by a smooth brain surface due to poor neuronal migration and the absence of gyri.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 11,992

choices.text: Bacterial meningitis
Tubercular meningitis
Fungal meningitis.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl named Malika is brought to the clinic by her mother with symptoms of acute fever and vomiting. The mother reports that the child has been avoiding loud sounds and bright lights from a recent family wedding by staying in her room for the past two days. During the examination, the child exhibits a sign that raises the suspicion of meningitis. A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample is collected and analyzed, yielding the following results: lymphocyte count of 150 cells/mm^3, CSF protein level of 110 mg%, and CSF glucose level of 75 mg%. Based on the clinical features and CSF findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aseptic meningitis.

 

Option D:

 

Aseptic/ Viral meningitis is suggested by the presence of lymphocytic pleocytosis (elevated lymphocyte count in the CSF), an elevated protein level, and a normal glucose level in the CSF. These findings are consistent with viral meningitis, which is a common cause of aseptic meningitis. The child's avoidance of bright lights (photophobia) and loud sounds (phonophobia) along with the presence of fever and vomiting support this diagnosis.

 

Characteristic 

 

  • Kernig’s sign positive
  • CSF - raised lymphocytes, raised protein and normal glucose

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis:

Bacterial meningitis is often associated with a rapid onset of symptoms, including fever, vomiting, and signs of meningeal irritation such as neck stiffness.

  • The CSF findings in bacterial meningitis typically show an elevated white blood cell count (predominantly neutrophils), elevated protein, and decreased glucose levels. In this case, the CSF profile (lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal glucose) is not consistent with bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Tubercular meningitis:

  • Tubercular meningitis is a form of meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • The CSF findings in tubercular meningitis may show lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. However, the clinical presentation and CSF findings in this case do not strongly suggest tubercular meningitis.

 

Option C. Fungal meningitis:

 

  • Fungal meningitis is rare and is usually seen in individuals with compromised immune systems.
  • The CSF findings in fungal meningitis may include lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal to mildly decreased glucose. However, the clinical presentation and CSF findings in this case are not highly suggestive of fungal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aseptic meningitis refers to non-bacterial, non-tubercular, and non-fungal causes of meningitis. Viral infections are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis.
  • The CSF findings in aseptic meningitis often include lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal glucose.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 6852

choices.text: Myelomeningocele
Meningocele.
Spina bifida occulta
Omphalocele

questions.text: A 7-day-old newborn is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about the growth of extra hair on his back. Upon physical examination, the doctor observes the appearance of the child’s back as shown in the image. To further investigate the possibility of a congenital anomaly, an ultrasound (USG) is recommended. Which of the following conditions might the ultrasound reveal in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spina bifida occulta

 

 

Option C:

  • The child in the photograph has a hairy nevus over the spine which is seen in case of Spina bifida occulta.
  • Prompt evaluation of these lesions via CT, MRI or ultrasound is indicated to confirm this case.
  • This remains usually asymptomatic.
  • This tuft of hair presentation can also be seen in Dermal sinus and Spinal lipoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myelomeningocele:

 

  • Myelomeningocele is a severe form of neural tube defect where the spinal canal and backbone do not close properly during fetal development. This results in a sac-like protrusion containing the spinal cord and meninges.
  • While myelomeningocele can present with abnormal skin and hair growth, it is typically a more prominent and severe defect. Ultrasound may reveal a visible sac on the back.

 

Option B. Meningocele:

 

  • Meningocele is another type of neural tube defect where the meninges protrude through an opening in the spine, forming a sac.
  • Similar to myelomeningocele, meningocele may present with abnormal skin and hair growth, and ultrasound can reveal the presence of a sac on the back.

 

Option D. Omphalocele:

 

  • Omphalocele is a congenital anomaly where the baby's abdominal organs protrude through the belly button (umbilicus) and are covered by a sac.
  • This condition is not typically associated with abnormal hair growth on the back, and ultrasound findings would focus on the abdominal region rather than the spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spina bifida occulta is a mild form of neural tube defect where the spinal cord and meninges do not protrude through the opening in the spine. It is often covered by skin and may not cause noticeable external abnormalities.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-2805 -2806.

choices.text: Pseudotumor cerebri
Tubercular meningitis
Viral meningitis
Acute bacterial meningitis

questions.text: A 7-year-old child undergoes a lumbar puncture, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample is shown in the image. Clinically, the child presents with mild fever, nuchal rigidity, and intermittent stupor. CSF analysis reveals 85 white blood cells per microliter, all of which are lymphocytes, a negative Gram stain, a protein level of 150 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 15 mg/dL. A CT scan with contrast demonstrates enhancement of the basal cisterns. Based on the clinical presentation and examination findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubercular meningitis

 

Option B:

 

  • Based on the clinical history of mild fever and intermittent stupor along with neck rigidity, it’s classically a case of Tubercular meningitis.
  • The CT scan with contrast can be an excellent clue for diagnosing tubercular meningitis. Exudate in the basal cisterns that show enhancement by contrast material is typical.
  • The CSF findings include- Raised lymphocytes, raised protein and decreased CSF glucose.
  • The physical examination of CSF will show the Cob web coagulum.
  • The treatment is starting with ATT and Steroids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudotumor cerebri:

 

  • Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension) is characterized by increased intracranial pressure without an obvious cause. It can cause headaches and visual disturbances.
  • The CSF findings in pseudotumor cerebri typically show an increased opening pressure but do not exhibit the significant lymphocytic pleocytosis seen in the provided scenario.

 

Option C. Viral meningitis:

 

  • Viral meningitis is often characterized by a milder course than bacterial meningitis. It commonly presents with fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity.
  • The CSF findings in viral meningitis typically show lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal or slightly elevated protein, and normal glucose. The enhancement of basal cisterns is not a typical feature.

 

Option D. Acute bacterial meningitis:

 

  • Acute bacterial meningitis is a medical emergency with a rapid onset of symptoms, including fever, severe headache, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status.
  • The CSF findings in acute bacterial meningitis often show neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. The enhancement of basal cisterns is less commonly seen compared to tubercular meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is characterized by a subacute or chronic course. It commonly presents with fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status.
  • The CSF findings in tubercular meningitis often show lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. The enhancement of basal cisterns on contrast-enhanced CT is a characteristic feature.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-562-563.

choices.text: Dandy walker malformation
Arnold Chiari Malformation

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl named Inaya is brought to the clinic by her mother due to concerns about intellectual disability and refractory seizures. Despite her normal physical appearance, a spine X-ray indicates the presence of hemivertebrae. What is the most likely diagnosis considering the clinical features and radiological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aicardi syndrome.

 

Option D:

 

  • Aicardi syndrome represents a complex disorder that affects many systems and is typically associated with agenesis of the corpus callosum, distinctive chorio-retinal lacunae, and infantile spasms.
  • Seizures become evident during the 1st few months and are typically resistant to anticonvulsants.
  • An EEG shows independent activity recorded from both hemispheres as a result of the absent corpus callosum and shows often hemihypsarrhythmia.
  • MRI will show the agenesis of Corpus callosum.
  • All patients have severe intellectual disability and can have abnormal vertebrae that may be fused or only partially developed (hemi vertebra).
  • Abnormalities of the retina, including circumscribed pits or lacunae and coloboma of the optic disc, are the most characteristic findings of Aicardi syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dandy Walker Malformation:

 

  • This condition involves a problem with the development of the cerebellum and its surrounding fluid-filled spaces. It can cause issues with coordination and movement.

 

Option B. Arnold Chiari Malformation:

 

  • In Arnold Chiari Malformation, the lower part of the brain (cerebellar tonsils) extends into the spinal canal, potentially leading to problems with coordination and swallowing.

 

Option C. Hydrocephalus:

 

  • This condition involves an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain, leading to increased pressure. It can cause symptoms such as headaches and vision problems.
  • Learning Objective: Comprehend the basic features of hydrocephalus, recognize clinical manifestations and radiological findings, and distinguish it from other conditions with similar presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aicardi Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by intellectual disability, refractory seizures, and specific brain abnormalities, as indicated by the presence of Hemi vertebrae in this case.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 557.

choices.text: Respiratory Distress syndrome.
Grade IV Intraventricular hemorrhage
Apnea of prematurity
Retinopathy of prematurity stage 1

questions.text: An infant girl is born prematurely at 29 weeks of gestation due to an incompetent cervix and undergoes spontaneous vaginal delivery. Given the risks associated with prematurity, the neonate is closely monitored and admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). Which aspect of her clinical course in the NICU is most likely to correlate with her long-term clinical outcome five years in the future?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grade IV Intraventricular hemorrhage.

 

Option B:

 

Intraventricular hemorrhage is a complication in preterm infants.

 

It is associated with seizures, hydrocephalus, and periventricular leukomalacia.

 

A grade IV bleed involves the brain parenchyma, putting this child at higher risk for neurodevelopmental handicap.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS):

 

  • Description: RDS is a common respiratory complication in preterm infants due to immature lungs, leading to difficulty breathing.
  • Significance: While RDS can have immediate implications, its severity may not always be the strongest predictor of long-term outcomes.

 

Option C. Apnea of Prematurity:

 

  • Description: Apnea of prematurity is a temporary cessation of breathing for >20 seconds in preterm infants due to immature respiratory centers in the brain.
  • Significance: While apnea is significant in the neonatal period, its correlation with long-term outcomes may not be as direct as with certain neurological complications.

 

Option D. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) Stage 1:

 

  • Description: ROP is an eye disorder in preterm infants, and Stage 1 is the least severe form, involving abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina.
  • Significance: ROP, especially in its early stages, may not be as strongly correlated with long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes compared to severe intraventricular hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grade IV IVH is the most severe form of bleeding into the brain's ventricles in preterm infants.
  • Significance: Severe IVH is associated with an increased risk of long-term neurodevelopmental issues, making it a potential predictor of clinical outcomes.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 3934

choices.text: 20 mL/hr
30 mL/hr
40 mL/hr
50 mL/hr

questions.text: A mother brings her newborn to the clinic, concerned about the baby's head, which appears enlarged and features visible veins. The physician, after evaluating the newborn, determines that the baby's condition is due to a disruption in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow, leading to accumulation. While discussing the diagnosis and implications with the family, the mother's sister inquires about normal CSF production in a child. What is the normal rate of CSF production in a child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20 mL/hr

 

Explanation:

 

The normal rate of CSF production in a child is approximately 20 mL/hr. CSF is produced by the choroid plexuses located in the ventricles of the brain and the rate remains relatively constant. This production leads to a total turnover of CSF about three to four times per day in both children and adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal production of CSF in an infant is 20 mL/hr.

 

Overproduction or under excretion, resulting from an obstruction in the CSF flow pathway will result in Hydrocephalus.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-578.

choices.text: There will be marginal change in the CSF production
Any sport which has adrenergic rise has no correlation with CSF production
Stimulation of the adrenergic system diminishes CSF production, whereas excitation of the cholinergic nerves may double the normal CSF production rate.
Excitation of the cholinergic nerves will decrease the normal CSF production rate.

questions.text: While enjoying a day at the theme park, a medical student observes a 2-year-old child eager to go on a thrilling ride. This scene prompts the student to reflect on a recent discussion regarding the effects of various activities on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) production. By the end of the ride, characterized by excitement and potentially an adrenergic response, what change in CSF production might be expected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stimulation of the adrenergic system diminishes CSF production, whereas excitation of the cholinergic nerves may double the normal CSF production rate.

 

Option C:

 

The autonomic nervous system influences CSF production. Stimulation of the adrenergic system, which may occur during intense activities or stress (Fight or Flight Stimuli such as riding a roller coaster), has been shown to reduce CSF production. Conversely, activation of the cholinergic system can increase CSF production. This is due to the influence these systems have on the choroid plexus epithelium, where CSF is produced.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. There will be marginal change in the CSF production: The statement does not provide information about the specific activities or conditions that might affect CSF production.

 

Option B. Any sport which has adrenergic rise has no correlation with CSF production: The statement is overly general and doesn't accurately reflect the relationship between adrenergic activity and CSF production.

 

Option D. Excitation of the cholinergic nerves will decrease the normal CSF production rate: While it correctly states the impact of cholinergic stimulation on CSF production, it doesn't provide a complete picture of the adrenergic system's effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenergic stimulation reduces CSF production, while cholinergic excitation may double it.

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-578.

choices.text: The lesion seen in the image is seen in Louis-bar syndrome
The lesion seen in the image is seen in Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
The lesion seen in the image is seen in tuberous sclerosis
The lesion seen in the image is seen in Von Recklinghausen disease

questions.text: A mother brings her child to the clinic, concerned about abnormal findings in the child's eyes, as shown in the image provided. Based on the eye findings depicted in the image, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The lesion seen in the image is seen in Von Recklinghausen disease

 

Option D:

 

The lesions in the image are indicative of Lisch nodules, which are iris hamartomas typically associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), also known as Von Recklinghausen disease. These nodules are melanocytic in origin and are one of the diagnostic criteria for NF1. They do not impair vision and are not present at birth but develop during childhood or adolescence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The lesion seen in the image is seen in Louis-Bar syndrome: Louis-Bar syndrome is another term for Ataxia-telangiectasia, a different genetic disorder characterized by cerebellar ataxia and telangiectasias.

 

Option B. The lesion seen in the image is seen in Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome: A genetic disorder characterized by the development of tumors and cysts in various organs, including the eyes. The ocular findings in Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome usually involve retinal hemangioblastomas.

 

Option C. The lesion seen in the image is seen in tuberous sclerosis: A genetic disorder that leads to the growth of noncancerous tumors in various organs. Retinal hamartomas can be observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Recklinghausen disease/ Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder characterized by multiple neurofibromas. Lisch nodules on the iris are characteristic of NF 1 and can aid in the diagnosis of this condition

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No-12251

choices.text: Keep it open and let it dry to avoid infection
Urgent surgery is only the best option
Keep it moist by applying Meningomyelocele covered with sterile saline soaked gauze to prevent it from drying, trauma and infection
Wait and watch under phototherapy as it has shown some benefits in reducing the size of defect

questions.text: A 20-day-old infant is brought to the pediatric department by the mother due to a significant congenital finding on the child's lower back, as depicted in the image. As the pediatrician in charge, you examine the child and determine that surgical intervention is necessary and is scheduled for the following morning. In preparation for surgery and to care for the child's wound, what is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keep it moist by applying Meningomyelocele covered with sterile saline soaked gauze to prevent it from drying, trauma and infection.

 

Option C:

 

For a child with a meningomyelocele, it is crucial to prevent the sac from drying out and to protect it from trauma and infection before surgical repair. This is typically done by covering the lesion with sterile saline-soaked gauze. Keeping the area moist helps maintain the integrity of the sac and the tissue within it, reducing the risk of infection and further damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Allowing the sac to dry could lead to tearing and an increased risk of infection.

 

Option B. While urgent surgery is important, it is not the only management option before the operation. Pre-operative care is essential to ensure the best possible surgical outcome.

 

Option D. Phototherapy has no proven benefit in reducing the size of a meningomyelocele and is not part of the pre-operative care for this condition. Phototherapy is used in neonatal jaundice

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meningomyelocele should be always covered with sterile saline soaked gauze to prevent it from drying, trauma and infection. This approach is consistent with the standard care for meningomyelocele to create a moist environment that aids in wound healing.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition,Page No-11980.

choices.text: 40 microgram
400 microgram
4000 microgram

questions.text: A mother with a history of giving birth to a child with a neural tube defect, as depicted in the image, was previously informed that the condition was due to inadequate folic acid intake. As she has had a child with this condition and is planning another pregnancy, she inquires about the recommended dosage of folic acid for secondary prophylaxis before conception. What is the correct dosage of folic acid to be prescribed in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4000 micrograms.

 

Explanation:

 

For women with a history of pregnancy affected by a neural tube defect, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and various clinical guidelines recommend a higher intake of folic acid as secondary prophylaxis. The recommended dosage is 4000 micrograms (4 milligrams) daily, starting at least one month before conception and continuing through the first trimester of pregnancy.

 

Note - 400 microgram: The standard dose of folic acid; generally recommended for women of childbearing age, especially as a preventive measure against neural tube defects during early pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate dose of folic acid for secondary prophylaxis in women with a history of a child with neural tube defects is 4000 micrograms.

 

The standard and recommended daily dose for primary prevention is 400 micrograms.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition,Page No-2805 -2806

choices.text: Chorioretinitis
Peri ventricular calcifications
Cataract
Hearing loss

questions.text: In a child with a history of congenital infection, you review radiological findings as shown below. Considering the typical outcomes of such infections, which of the following is the most common long-term sequelae?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hearing loss

 

Option D:

The radiological image suggests presence of periventricular calcification which is seen in case of congenital CMV.

Hearing loss is a prevalent long-term consequence, which is known to affect the auditory system. This can lead to sensorineural hearing loss, impacting the child's development and communication skills.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chorioretinitis:  While it can be associated with congenital CMV infection, it is not the most common long-term sequelae.

 

Option B. Peri ventricular calcifications: While calcifications can occur, they are not the primary and most common sequela.

 

Option C. Cataract: Although ocular abnormalities can occur, cataract is not the primary and most common sequela.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensorineural hearing loss is the most prevalent and impactful sequela in infants with congenital CMV infection

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, page number 4660

choices.text: Café au lait macules seen in Tuberous Sclerosis.
6 or more café au lait spots each of > 5 mm before puberty or >15 mm in older persons
2 or more café au lait spots each of > 3 mm before puberty or >13 mm in older persons
A+B is correct

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her child to your clinic, troubled by a birthmark that has attracted varied opinions in her community. While some neighbors regard it as a fortunate sign, a medical student has suggested it could indicate an underlying condition, causing the mother great distress. Upon examination, you observe the skin finding shown in the image. What is the correct statement regarding the skin finding observed in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 or more café au lait spots each of > 5 mm before puberty or >15 mm in older persons.

 

Option B:

 

The skin findings shown in the image are consistent with café au lait macules, which are often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). The diagnostic criteria for NF1 include the presence of six or more café au lait spots larger than 5 mm in diameter before puberty or larger than 15 mm after puberty. These spots are typically smooth-edged, evenly pigmented, and can increase in number and size with age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Café au lait macules / Seen in Tuberous Sclerosis: Café au lait macules are not typically associated with Tuberous Sclerosis; instead, they are associated with neurofibromatosis. Tuberous Sclerosis is associated with other skin findings like angiofibromas and hypomelanotic macules.

 

Option C. 2 or more café au lait spots each of > 3 mm before puberty or >13 mm in older persons: This option does not match the established diagnostic criteria for NF1 or any other related conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Café au lait macules are often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), and the correct criteria for diagnosis include having 6 or more café au lait spots, each of more than 5 mm in diameter before puberty, or more than 15 mm in diameter in older individuals.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No-12251

choices.text: Café au lait macules
Axillary freckling
These are small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin
Both B and C are true.

questions.text: A mother presents her child for evaluation, concerned about skin findings in the axilla. She mentions that the child's father also has similar skin changes and is known to have a neurocutaneous disorder. Upon examination, you observe the findings shown in the image. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both B and C are true.

 

Option D:

 

The image shows axillary freckling, also known as Crowe's sign, which is characterized by small, dark spots in the axillary region. These spots occur due to increased melanin and are considered a diagnostic criterion for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). NF1 is a neurocutaneous disorder that can present with multiple dermatological findings, including café au lait macules and axillary freckling.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Café au lait macules: While café au lait macules are associated with neurofibromatosis, the spots in the axilla shown in the image are consistent with axillary freckling, not café au lait macules.

 

Option B. Axillary freckling: This option is correct; the findings are indeed axillary freckling, which is associated with neurofibromatosis.

 

Option C. These are small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin: This description is accurate and describes the axillary freckling observed in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical diagnosis of NF1

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No-12251

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to a clinic by her mother in a small town in India, with a history of intermittent diarrhea, periumbilical pain, and bloating that have persisted for the last three years. The symptoms occasionally exacerbate after the intake of milk and dairy products. On physical examination, rashes around the umbilicus are noted. A Benedict's test performed during the visit yields positive results, indicating the presence of reducing sugars in the urine. Given that an enzyme deficiency affecting lactose metabolism is suspected, which of the following food items is the girl most likely to tolerate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yoghurt.

 

Option B:

 

Lactose intolerance (lactose maldigestion) is a common cause of paediatric recurrent abdominal pain.

 

  • Lactase is a digestive enzyme located on the intestinal villi that converts the disaccharide lactose to the monosaccharides glucose and galactose.
  • The monosaccharides can be absorbed across the intestinal epithelial cells. In an individual who has low intestinal lactase (lactose intolerance), the lactose cannot be broken down and passed into the lower intestine and colon.
  • The malabsorbed lactose can cause osmotic diarrhoea or be fermented by bacteria, resulting in pain, bloating and perianal rash.
  • Lactose intolerance can either be primary (lactase activity that gradually declines with aging) or secondary (an infection or enteropathy damages the villi, resulting in lactose intolerance).
  • Many patients who have lactose intolerance diagnosed can tolerate Yoghurt.
  • Other products such as whole or skimmed milk, ice cream, or buttermilk have more lactose (approximately 10 g/serving) and are less likely to be tolerated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Whole milk: Whole milk contains a significant amount of lactose and is therefore unlikely to be tolerated by someone with lactose intolerance.

 

Option C. Buttermilk: Buttermilk generally contains less lactose than whole milk but still may contain enough to cause symptoms in someone with lactose intolerance.

 

Option D. Skimmed milk: Skimmed milk contains a similar amount of lactose as whole milk and is therefore unlikely to be tolerated by someone with lactose intolerance.

 

Educational objective:

 

Yoghurt, is the most likely food that will be tolerated due to its lower lactose content compared to whole milk and skimmed milk, making it a suitable alternative for individuals with lactose intolerance.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 1854-1874. O P Ghai – Page No-293

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric outpatient department with a 5-month history of rectal bleeding, characterized by fresh blood clearly visible on the stool. The boy reports no significant constipation, vomiting, diarrhea, or weight loss. His diet is typical for his age, and he is growing appropriately. On examination, his abdomen is soft with mild tenderness on the right side, and stool is palpable in the descending colon. A sentinel skin tag is observed in the perianal area, but no fissures are present. Complete blood count (CBC) is within normal range, and both X-ray and histopathological examination (HPE) of the bowel show no abnormalities. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meckels diverticulum

 

Option D:

 

Meckels diverticulum is a congenital condition that can cause painless rectal bleeding, which may be fresh and mixed with stool. The presence of a sentinel skin tag could be associated with underlying rectal bleeding. Normal growth, absence of systemic symptoms like weight loss, vomiting, and diarrhea, and normal bowel habits make constipation and inflammatory bowel disease less likely. Campylobacter enterocolitis typically presents with diarrhea and systemic symptoms, which are not reported in this case.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Constipation: Could cause rectal bleeding due to anal fissures, but the patient denies significant constipation, and no fissure was found on examination.

 

Option B. Inflammatory bowel disease: Usually presents with diarrhea, weight loss, and systemic symptoms, which are not observed in this boy.

 

Option C. Campylobacter enterocolitis: This typically presents with diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain, which are not consistent with this patients history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckels diverticulum is a congenital abnormality of the small intestine and can present with symptoms such as painless rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, and occasionally intestinal obstruction.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 1854-1874.

questions.text: During a routine visit, a mother expresses concern about her 6-month-old child's frequent vomiting, which seems to be non-pathological upon examination. The child appears otherwise healthy with no detectable abnormalities. To address the mother's concerns and provide reassurance, you explain that this is a common occurrence in infants and not indicative of a serious condition. What would you identify as the most common cause of this vomiting in an otherwise healthy infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aerophagia

 

Option A:

 

Aerophagia is the most common cause of vomiting in children.

 

Aerophagia, hydrophagia, and milkophagia are conditions related to swallowing behaviors, each involving the excessive intake of a particular substance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hydrophagia: Hydrophagia refers to excessive drinking of water, which is not typically associated with frequent vomiting in infants unless it leads to water intoxication, which is rare and usually not a common cause of vomiting in this age group.

 

Option C. Milkophagia: "Milkophagia" is not a recognized medical term. However, excessive milk intake or overfeeding can lead to vomiting in infants, but it is less common compared to aerophagia, especially in the absence of other symptoms like poor weight gain or discomfort during feeding.

 

Option D. Esophageal atresia: Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition where the esophagus does not develop properly, leading to a gap or blockage. It typically presents with difficulty swallowing, choking, and regurgitation of feedings shortly after birth, rather than at 6 months of age. Additionally, there would likely be abnormalities seen on examination or imaging studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aerophagia refers to the swallowing of air, which can occur during feeding or crying in infants, leading to frequent episodes of vomiting. This is a common and benign cause of vomiting in infants, especially during the first few months of life when their feeding patterns are still developing.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition Chapter 368, Page No- 8087

choices.text: Till 3 years of life.
Till 2 years of life.
Till 1 year of life.
Till 4 years of life.

questions.text: A mother consults a pediatrician during a routine visit for her 9-month-old baby, expressing concern that the child isn't gaining adequate weight and frequently regurgitates feed hours after eating. The child also has recurrent episodes of coughing associated with the regurgitation. After evaluating the baby, the pediatrician reassures the mother that this is a case of physiological regurgitation, which is common and typically not a cause for concern. The mother then inquires about the age up to which this regurgitation is considered normal without indicating a more serious underlying issue. How should the pediatrician respond?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Till 1 year of life.

 

Explanation:

 

Clinical Manifestations Infantile reflux manifests more often with regurgitation (especially postprandially), signs of esophagitis (irritability, arching, choking, gagging, feeding aversion), and resulting failure to thrive; symptoms resolve spontaneously in the majority by 12 months.

 

Treatment – reassure the patient till 12 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological regurgitation of feeds is a common occurrence in infants, typically improving as they grow older and develop better control over their feeding and digestive systems. It is considered normal for regurgitation to occur until around 1 year of age in the absence of any concerning symptoms or underlying medical conditions.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter- 349– Page No- 7683.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn is brought to a hospital with symptoms of vomiting and an inability to pass meconium since birth. The physical examination reveals a noticeably distended abdomen and visible peristaltic waves. An X-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, but no air is seen beyond the proximal duodenum, suggesting a lack of passage through the distal duodenum and small intestine. Based on the clinical presentation and X-ray findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal atresia

 

Option B:

 

Double bubble" sign- This is the hallmark finding on X-ray. It shows a dilated stomach and a dilated duodenal bulb, creating the appearance of two bubbles side by side. The narrowed segment of the duodenum between these two bubbles causes the obstruction.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Projectile vomiting: Infants with duodenal atresia often have projectile vomiting, which can occur shortly after feeding. The vomiting is typically non-bilious, meaning it does not contain bile.
  • Abdominal distension: Due to the blockage in the duodenum, there is a build-up of fluid and gas in the stomach and proximal small intestine. This can cause abdominal distension and visible peristaltic waves.
  • Failure to pass meconium: Meconium is the first stool that newborn passes, and its absence can indicate a bowel obstruction.
  • Absent or decreased bowel sounds: A blockage in the duodenum can cause decreased or absent bowel sounds upon auscultation.
  • Polyhydramnios: In some cases, polyhydramnios (excessive amniotic fluid) may be present during pregnancy, which can be a sign of duodenal atresia in the fetus.
  • Down syndrome: Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with Down syndrome, and infants with this genetic condition may be screened for the condition.
  • Other associated anomalies: In some cases, duodenal atresia may be associated with other congenital anomalies such as cardiac defects, tracheoesophageal fistula, or imperforate anus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Esophageal atresia: Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a gap or blockage in the esophagus. It typically presents shortly after birth with drooling, choking, and difficulty swallowing, but it does not typically present with failure to pass meconium or a distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves. Additionally, the X-ray findings described are not consistent with esophageal atresia.

 

Option C. Hirschsprung's disease: Hirschsprung's disease is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of nerve cells in parts of the large intestine, leading to difficulty passing stool. It typically presents with symptoms of intestinal obstruction, such as failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, and vomiting. However, the X-ray findings described, including a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, are more indicative of a small bowel obstruction rather than Hirschsprung's disease, which primarily affects the large intestine.

 

Option D. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a blockage or narrowing in the jejunum, a part of the small intestine. It can present with symptoms similar to duodenal atresia, including vomiting, failure to pass meconium, and abdominal distension. However, the X-ray findings described, specifically the visualization of a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels, are more suggestive of a proximal small bowel obstruction, which is consistent with duodenal atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by a blockage or narrowing in the duodenum, the first part of the small intestine. It commonly presents in newborns with vomiting, failure to pass meconium, and a distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves. X-ray findings typically show a dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with air-fluid levels.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter- 356, – Page No- 7749.

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-month-old infant with complaints of sudden onset of intermittent, severe abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. The infant draws their legs up to their abdomen and cries loudly when the pain is present. On physical examination, there is a palpable sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. An abdominal x-ray reveals air-fluid levels and an USG revealed a target or bulls eye sign. What is the likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario and the radiographical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intussusception

 

Option D:

 

Intussusception – telescoping of a proximal segment of the intestine (intussusceptum) into a distal segment (intussuscipiens).

 

Occurs most often near the ileocecal junction (ileocolic intussusception)

 

The majority of cases in children are idiopathic.

 

Classic triad (<15% of cases)

 

  • Intermittent colicky abdominal pain
  • Sausage shaped abdominal mass
  • Red currant jelly stool is seen in less than 15% of patients at the time of presentation.
  • Occasionally, the initial presenting sign is lethargy or altered consciousness alone, without pain, rectal bleeding, or other symptoms that suggest an intra-abdominal process and is often confused with sepsis.

 

Clinical Manifestations

 

Patients with intussusception typically develop the sudden onset of intermittent, severe, crampy, progressive abdominal pain, accompanied by inconsolable crying and drawing up of the legs toward the abdomen.

 

  • Between symptoms child will be playing and doing normal activity. → Vomiting Later → Continuous abdominal pain
  • The stool may contains gross or occult blood or be a mixture of blood and mucous and sloughing mucosa, giving it the appearance of currant jelly.
  • Lethargy - Palpable abdominal mass.
  • Physical - A sausage shaped abdominal mass. - Abdominal distension and Dehydration.

 

Diagnosis

 

Ultrasonography - A Doughnut or ‘target sign’ is seen, representing layers of the intestine within the intestine.

 

Treatment - Stabilize and resuscitate with intravenous fluids Hydration, electrolyte, acid-base balance.

 

  • uncomplicated reduced with air enema 24-48 hrs
  • Non-operative reduction using hydrostatic or pneumatic pressure by enema
  • Risk of perforation – adv in pneumatic technique.
  • Surgical treatment -Indicated for patients with peritonitis or evidence of perforation or in whom non-operative reduction is unsuccessful.
  • Manual reduction at operation is attempted

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: It can cause pain and bleeding but is less likely to present with a palpable abdominal mass and the "bull's-eye" sign on ultrasound.

 

Option B. Duodenal atresia: Presents with early-onset vomiting, typically in neonates, and is associated with a "double bubble" sign on X-ray, not the findings described.

 

Option C. Hirschsprung's disease: Characterized by chronic constipation and abdominal distension due to a lack of enteric nervous system cells in the distal colon; it does not typically present acutely with a palpable mass and "bull's-eye" sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation and ultrasound findings of intussusception in infants, which include sudden, intermittent abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, a palpable sausage-shaped mass, and the "bull's-eye" sign on imaging. Early identification and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as bowel necrosis.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 1812-1814.

choices.text: It’s a true diverticulum.
It is due to persistence of omphalomesenteric duct.
May have ectopic acid-secreting gastric mucosa.
Least common congenital anomaly of gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 3-year-old son, who has no significant medical history, to the pediatric clinic after discovering bright red blood in his diaper. The child seems relatively comfortable, except for when his right lower quadrant (RLQ) is palpated, causing him to cry. An ultrasound reveals a tubular blind-ending structure originating from an ileal loop, and a technetium-99m scan confirms the presence of Meckel's diverticulum. Considering the diagnosis of Meckel's diverticulum, which of the following statements is NOT true about its features?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Least common congenital anomaly of gastrointestinal tract

 

Option D:

 

Meckel’s diverticulum:

 

Congenital diverticulum presenting in childhood

 

It’s a “true” diverticulum, with all 3 layers of the gut wall out pouched

 

Pathogenesis

 

  • Persistence of vitelline (omphalomesenteric) duct in small intestine  
  • May have ectopic acid-secreting gastric or pancreatic tissue

 

Presentation:

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Painless rectal bleeding -due to gastric acid secretion causing damage to small bowel tissue
  • Normal abdominal examination
  • May serve as lead point for intussusception
  • Small bowel obstruction

 

Evaluation

 

Most commonly discovered as incidental finding on laparotomy

 

  • Technetium-99m scan aka Meckel scan
  • Most accurate test
  • Technetium-99m pertechnetate radioisotope is taken up by ectopic gastric mucosa

 

Treatment: Surgical removal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. True Diverticulum: Correct. Meckel's diverticulum involves all layers of the bowel wall.

 

Option B. Persistence of Omphalomesenteric Duct: Correct, as Meckel's diverticulum results from the failure of the omphalomesenteric duct to completely obliterate during development.

 

Option C. Ectopic Acid-Secreting Gastric Mucosa: Correct. The presence of ectopic gastric mucosa can lead to acid secretion and subsequent ulceration, causing bleeding, which might explain the rectal bleeding in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most common congenital anomaly of gastrointestinal tract - Meckel’s diverticulum

 

Rule of 2’s

 

  • Affects 2% of population
  • 2 feet from ileocecal valve
  • 2 inches long
  • 2 types of epithelia tissue: gastric and pancreatic
  • Male: female ratio 2:1
  • Patients < 2 years old
  • 2% symptomatic

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition Chapter 357 – Page No- 7762

questions.text: An anxious mother consults about her 2-year-old child, who exhibits delayed developmental milestones, signs of intellectual disability, and sandal gap toes. The child, recently diagnosed with a heart condition, is also identified to have a trisomy disorder. Accompanying this information is an image depicting the child's eye findings characteristic of the trisomy disorder. Given this clinical background, what is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal atresia.

 

Option B:

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical findings is Trisomy 21 which is Down syndrome.

 

Duodenal atresia is most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome.

 

The clinical features of Downs syndrome (trisomy 21) are.

 

  • Flat facial profile and an upward slant to the eye.
  • Short neck
  • Abnormally shaped ears
  • White spots on the iris of the eye (Brushfield spots)
  • Single, deep transverse crease on the palm of the hand.
  • Brachycephaly
  • Protruding tongue
  • Presenile Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Meckel's Diverticulum: While Meckel's diverticulum is a common congenital anomaly, it is not particularly associated with Down syndrome more than duodenal atresia.

 

Option C. Hirschsprung Disease: This condition involves the absence of ganglion cells in the bowel leading to functional obstruction. It is not specifically associated with Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Jejunal Atresia: Though a possible cause of intestinal obstruction in neonates, jejunal atresia does not have a specific association with Down syndrome like duodenal atresia does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in the Down Syndrome child is duodenal atresia.

 

Duodenal atresia is notably associated with Down syndrome, with up to 30% of infants with duodenal atresia having Down syndrome.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 98- Page No 3011.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a 26-month-old child presents with unique facial characteristics such as doll-like facies, frontal bossing, and a depressed nasal bridge. The child, notably shorter than peers, has a proportionate body structure. An evaluation indicates a delayed bone age compared to the chronological age. Given these findings, which condition is least likely to account for the child's proportionate short stature?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Achondroplasia.

 

Option D:

 

Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder characterized by disproportionate dwarfism, typically presenting with short limbs relative to the trunk and specific craniofacial abnormalities. Given the child's proportionate short stature and the absence of limb disproportion, achondroplasia is the least likely cause among the options provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Growth Hormone Deficiency: This condition can lead to proportionate short stature due to a uniform reduction in growth velocity but would not typically result in the specific craniofacial features described.

 

Option B. Constitutional Delay: This common, benign condition can cause temporary proportionate short stature and delayed bone age, aligning with the child's presentation except for the distinct facial features.

 

Option C. Malnutrition: Chronic malnutrition can result in proportionate short stature and delayed bone age, but may not account for the specific facial characteristics observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia

 

  • An AD disorder because of mutation in FGFR3 gene.
  • It leads to abnormal enchondral ossification.
  • Rizhomelic limb shortening
  • Disproportionate short stature
  • Champagne glass pelvis.

 

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition. Page 14368

questions.text: A mother, residing in a region where hypothyroidism is not endemic, brings her child to the clinic due to failure to thrive and delayed developmental milestones. The pediatric examination notes the child's hoarse cry, mottled skin, and distinct facial and abdominal features. Considering these clinical presentations, what is the most common cause of the child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid dysgenesis

 

Option B:

 

The clinical features and the image of a baby with umbilical hernia, large tongue and hypotonia are suggestive of Congenital hypothyroidism, the most common cause of Congenital hypothyroidism is Thyroid dysgenesis.

 

Untreated case may lead to

 

  • Intellectual disability
  • Disproportionate stature
  • Delayed bone maturation and
  • Delayed puberty.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is associated with positive family history in Congenital hypothyroidism cases.

 

Option C. Hashimoto's thyroiditis: This is an autoimmune condition leading to hypothyroidism, more common in older children and adults, and less likely in very young children presenting with congenital features.

 

Option D. Graves' disease: Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism in adolescents and its symptoms would contrast with those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism, accounting for approximately 85% of cases. It includes a spectrum of developmental abnormalities such as ectopic thyroid tissue, hypoplastic thyroid gland, or complete absence of the gland. These developmental issues lead to insufficient thyroid hormone production, which is critical for growth and development, thus explaining the child's symptoms.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 581 Page No- 11398-11423

Ghai Essential Pediatrics 8th Edition, Page No-516-519.

questions.text: In the pediatric ward, a 7-month-old baby has been diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism. As part of an educational exercise, you're discussing the case with a junior colleague, highlighting the clinical features of the condition. To test their understanding, you ask which of the following features is not typically associated with congenital hypothyroidism. How should your colleague respond?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Microglossia.

 

Microglossia is not a feature of congenital hypothyroidism, whereas Macroglossia is a feature.

 

The other features of congenital hypothyroidism include

 

  • Failure to thrive
  • Delayed development of milestones
  • Hoarse cry
  • Mottling of skin
  • Jaundice
  • Increased sleep
  • Macroglossia and
  • Hypotonia

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Failure to thrive: This is a common feature in congenital hypothyroidism due to the lack of thyroid hormones, which are crucial for growth and development.

 

Option B. Delayed development of milestones: Hypothyroidism can significantly impact neurological development, leading to Mental retardation and delays in achieving other age-appropriate milestones.

 

Option C. Constipation: Reduced levels of thyroid hormones can decrease gastrointestinal motility, leading to constipation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microglossia, the condition of having an unusually small tongue, is not associated with congenital hypothyroidism. In contrast, congenital hypothyroidism is more commonly linked with macroglossia, where the tongue is enlarged, which can lead to feeding and breathing difficulties, as well as an altered facial appearance.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 581 Page No- 11398-11423

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 8-year-old to the clinic due to abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding that started yesterday morning. Upon evaluation, the child displays signs of precocious puberty, café au lait spots, and fibrous dysplasia, leading to a diagnosis of McCune-Albright Syndrome (MAS). Considering the diagnosis, which endocrine anomaly is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rickets

 

McCune-Albright syndrome is a complex disorder involving mutations that affect the GNAS1 gene, leading to constitutive activation of the cyclic AMP pathway.

 

McCune Albright syndrome, has a triad of

 

  • precocious puberty
  • café au lait spots and
  • polyostotic fibrous dysplasia.

 

 

The endocrine abnormalities associated with this are

 

  • Hyperthyroidism,
  • GH excess,
  • Precocious puberty and
  • Rickets

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: While thyroid function can be affected in MAS, hypothyroidism is not a hallmark feature of this condition.

 

Option B. GH deficiency: Growth hormone deficiency is not typically associated with MAS. Instead, MAS can involve conditions like acromegaly due to growth hormone excess.

 

Option C. Delayed puberty: MAS is more commonly associated with precocious puberty rather than delayed puberty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McCune-Albright Syndrome (MAS) is characterized by a triad of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait skin pigmentation, and a variety of endocrine disorders, including precocious puberty, rickets, hyperthyroidism, etc.

 

Ref- OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-530

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy, who has been managing a condition with the aid of a syringe and medication for the past 5 years, presents with a recent random blood sugar (RBS) value of 158 mg/dl while on medication. Intrigued by an Instagram post about his condition, he inquires about the diagnostic criteria for his illness. Which of the following is not a recognized diagnostic criterion for the disease he is likely managing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fasting blood sugar of > 150mg/dl.

 

The image shown here is the insulin. So, the child is suffering from the Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus.

 

The diagnostic criteria for DM  

 

  • Fasting blood sugar of > 126mg/dl.
  • Random blood sugar of > 200mg/dl.
  • HbA1C of >6.5%

 

Dose of glucose for OGTT in children is 1.75g/kg of ideal body weight.

 

Treatment of choice for Type 1 DM is Insulin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fasting blood sugar > 126mg/dl: This is a standard criterion for the diagnosis of diabetes.

 

Option B. Random blood sugar > 200mg/dl: A random blood sugar level exceeding 200 mg/dl, especially when accompanied by classic symptoms of diabetes, can be diagnostic.

 

Option D. HbA1C > 6.5%: An HbA1C level greater than 6.5% is a well-recognized diagnostic criterion for diabetes, reflecting average blood glucose levels over the past 2-3 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard diagnostic criteria for diabetes include a fasting blood sugar (FBS) level greater than 126 mg/dl

 

Ref; Ghai Essential Paediatrics 10th Edition, Page No-546.

choices.text: Congenital GH deficiency, rhGH (S/c)

questions.text:
A mother brings her 12-month-old son to the pediatric department due to concerns about delayed dentition and a doll-like facial appearance. Despite appearing overweight, the child's weight-for-height ratio is normal, and he exhibits proportionate short stature. He was of average size at birth. Investigations reveal decreased levels of Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-1) and Growth Hormone (GH), with GH levels below 8 ng/ml. Based on the clinical presentation and investigation results, what is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate treatment?

*rhGH- High purity recombinant human growth hormone.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Congenital GH deficiency, rhGH (S/c)

 

Option A:

 

The diagnosis based on the history of the child is Congenital GH deficiency, the child is normal at birth because of maternal GH

 

Clinical features of GH deficiency in children are,

 

  • Doll like facies (normal GH promotes lipolysis),
  • Frontal bossing,
  • Depressed nasal bridge and
  • Proportionate short stature.

 

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • GH stimulation test,
  • Peak GH level <10ng/ml.
  • bone age less than chronological age.

 

Treatment for this condition is sub cutaneous rhGH (recombinant human growth hormone).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Congenital GH deficiency, rhGH (I/m): While intramuscular (I/m) administration is possible, subcutaneous (S/c) administration of rhGH is preferred due to better absorption and patient comfort.

 

Option C. & Option D. Acquired GH deficiency: Given the child's age and symptoms manifesting early in life, a congenital rather than acquired deficiency is more likely. Acquired GH deficiency usually occurs later in life due to injury, tumor, or radiation therapy affecting the pituitary gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delayed dentition, doll-like facies, proportionate short stature, normal weight for height, along with decreased IGF-1 and low GH levels, strongly suggests congenital growth hormone deficiency. This condition is present from birth and can lead to various growth delays without timely intervention. The recommended treatment is recombinant human growth hormone (rhGH) therapy, typically administered via subcutaneous (S/c) injections, which is the most effective and commonly used route for GH therapy.

 

Ref; Ghai Essential Paediatrics 10th Edition

questions.text: A 15-month-old child is brought to the emergency department at 6 AM by his mother due to seizures. After the seizure is controlled, the pediatrician's examination reveals deaf mutism and severe intellectual disability in the child. Additionally, a midline neck swelling is noted. During the conversation, the mother recalls that she forgot to take her morning medication for a disease that is common in the area. Based on the child's symptoms and the regional prevalence of a specific condition, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Endemic cretinism

 

Option D:

 

Endemic cretinism is a form of congenital iodine deficiency syndrome that occurs in regions where iodine deficiency is prevalent. It can lead to hypothyroidism in the mother, which, if untreated during pregnancy, can cause severe developmental issues in the child, including intellectual disability, hearing loss (deaf mutism), and even neurological problems like seizures. The midline neck swelling could indicate a goiter, which is common in iodine deficiency disorders.

 

Cretinism is of two types-neurological and myxedematous

Neurological- Low IQ, spasticity, seizures, deaf mutism and goiter.

 

Myxedematous-Puffy and dull looking face, loss of eyebrows and absence of goiter.

 

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism (cretinism) are:

 

  • Failure to thrive,
  • Delayed development of milestones,
  • Hoarse cry,
  • Mottling of skin,
  • Macroglossia and
  • Hypotonia.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thyroid dysgenesis: This refers to a congenital malformation or absence of the thyroid gland, leading to hypothyroidism, but it does not typically present with seizures or is associated with maternal medication.

 

Option B. Pendred syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and thyroid goiter, but the link to maternal medication and the acute presentation with seizures are less typical.

 

Option C. Maternal autoantibodies: While maternal autoantibodies can lead to transient hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism in the newborn, the severe symptoms and the reference to a common regional disease suggest endemic cretinism is more likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cretinism is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of thyroid hormones (congenital hypothyroidism).

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 581 Page No- 11398-11423

choices.text: It is an Autosomal recessive condition.
Most common enzyme deficient is 21 Hydroxylase.
17- hydroxy progesterone levels will be decreased.

questions.text: A female child presents with ambiguous genitalia, dry skin, reduced skin turgor, low blood pressure (80/50 mmHg), and hypoglycemia. Further tests reveal elevated potassium levels (6 mmol/L), leading to a diagnosis of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH). Considering the characteristics of CAH, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 17- hydroxy progesterone levels will be decreased.

 

Option D:

 

In CAH, particularly due to 21-Hydroxylase deficiency, there is an accumulation of steroid precursors before the enzymatic block, leading to elevated levels of 17-hydroxyprogesterone, not decreased levels. This is a key diagnostic marker for CAH.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is an Autosomal recessive condition: This statement is true. CAH is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Option B. The most common enzyme deficiency is 21-Hydroxylase: True. The majority of CAH cases are due to a deficiency in the 21-Hydroxylase enzyme.

 

Option C. It involves a mutation on chromosome 6: This statement is true. The gene responsible for 21-Hydroxylase, CYP21A2, is located on chromosome 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is an Autosomal recessive condition,

 

  • Most common enzyme deficient is 21 Hydroxylase
  • Mutation of chromosome no 6.

 

Features of 21 Hydroxylase deficiency are

 

  • Ambiguous genitalia,
  • Salt wasting,
  • Dehydration,
  • Hyperkalemia,
  • Hypoglycemia and
  • Shock.

 

 

Diagnosis: increased 17- hydroxy progesterone levels.

 

Treatment: Lifelong Hydrocortisone or fludrocortisone.

 

Ref; OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics  8th Edition, Page No-526.

choices.text: It indicates the cumulative heat exposure over time.
We can use the vial if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle.
The sticker indicates the efficacy of the vaccine over a period of time.
We can’t use the vial if the inner square is of darker than the outer circle.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the rural health clinic for his scheduled vaccination. As you are preparing the vaccine, a newly joined nurse assisting you points out the sticker on the vial and asks about its significance. The sticker is as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the sticker on the vaccine vial?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The sticker indicates the efficacy of the vaccine over a period of time.

 

Option C:

 

The sticker, known as a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM), does not indicate the efficacy of the vaccine itself; rather, it indicates whether the vaccine has been stored under suitable temperature conditions and thus retains its potency up until the point of administration. The change in color of the VVM is a direct response to heat exposure and not to the actual efficacy of the vaccine, which is determined by clinical trials and manufacturing processes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This statement is true. The VVM does indicate the cumulative heat exposure over time, which helps health workers determine if the vaccine has been stored appropriately.

 

Option B. This statement is also true. The VVM allows health workers to use the vial if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle, suggesting that the vaccine has not been compromised by excessive heat.

 

 

Grade I & II – can be used

Grade III & IV – CANNOT be used

 

Option D. This statement is true as well. If the inner square is darker than the outer circle, it is an indication that the vaccine may have been exposed to heat beyond the recommended levels and therefore should not be used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM)

 

  • It indicates the cumulative heat exposure over time.
  • We can use the vial if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle.
  • We can’t use the vial if the inner square is of darker than the outer circle.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No-203.

choices.text: Fever and irritability- recommend Paracetamol for fever control.
Vomiting and diarrhoea- recommend increased fluid intake and oral rehydration therapy.
Rash and itching- recommend topical steroids for symptomatic relief.
Cough and congestion- recommend antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her infant son, Raghav, to the local clinic in rural India for his scheduled vaccinations. After receiving the oral live rotavirus vaccine, the mother inquires about potential side effects. The nurse, seeking to provide accurate information, turns to you and asks what the most common side effect of the rotavirus vaccine in infants is and how it should be managed. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vomiting and diarrhoea- recommend increased fluid intake and oral rehydration therapy.

 

Option B:

 

The most common side effects following rotavirus vaccination are mild and include temporary vomiting and diarrhea. Management of these symptoms primarily involves preventing dehydration by increasing fluid intake and using oral rehydration therapy, especially in the Indian rural setting where intravenous therapy might not be immediately accessible. The use of oral rehydration salts (ORS) is common and recommended by health authorities worldwide for managing mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fever and irritability may occur following many types of vaccinations and are generally managed with antipyretics like Paracetamol. However, these are not the most common side effects of the rotavirus vaccine.

 

Option C. Rash and itching are not typical side effects of the rotavirus vaccine and would not be the first concern following vaccination.

 

Option D. Cough and congestion are more commonly associated with respiratory vaccines, like the influenza vaccine, and are not typical side effects of the rotavirus vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common side effect of Rota vaccine in infants is vomiting and diarrhoea.
  • This side effect typically occurs within the first week after vaccination and resolves within a few days without any specific treatment.
  • However, the child should be monitored closely for signs of dehydration, such as decreased urine output, dry mouth, and sunken fontanelles.
  • The appropriate management of Rota vaccine-associated vomiting and diarrhoea is to increase fluid intake and provide oral rehydration therapy.
  • Oral rehydration therapy should be given to prevent dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

 

Ref: OP Ghai Page No- 185-193.

choices.text: The vaccine causes bowel obstruction- immediate surgery is recommended.
The vaccine stimulates the immune system- recommend immunosuppressants.
The vaccine causes inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract- recommend anti-inflammatory drugs for symptom relief.
The vaccine virus strain has a structural similarity to the host's intestine, leading to intussusception- refer to a paediatric surgeon.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is rushed to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody stools. The mother reports that the child received an oral rotavirus vaccine two weeks prior. An ultrasound examination is performed, yielding the image displayed. Based on the clinical presentation and the ultrasound findings, the physician suspects intussusception. What is the most likely mechanism behind the association of intussusception with the rotavirus vaccine, and what is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The vaccine virus strain has a structural similarity to the host's intestine, leading to intussusception, refer to a paediatric surgeon.

 

Option D:

 

Intussusception is a condition in which one segment of the bowel telescopes into the adjacent segment, causing bowel obstruction, ischemia, and potential necrosis.

 

  • The mechanism behind the association of intussusception and Rota vaccine is believed to be related to the structural similarity between the vaccine virus strain and the host's intestine.
  • The virus strain used in the vaccine has a similar structure to the intestine, leading to an abnormal immune response, inflammation, serving as a potential pathological lead point, eventually causing intussusception.
  • This condition typically occurs within the first week after vaccination.
  • The appropriate management of intussusception associated with Rota vaccine is referral to a paediatric surgeon for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Surgery is often necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications.
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent bowel necrosis and sepsis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While bowel obstruction is a component of intussusception, the statement that the vaccine causes this obstruction is misleading. Immediate surgery may be recommended, but this is not due to the vaccine causing the obstruction directly.

 

Option B. The vaccine stimulates the immune system as part of its intended action, but recommending immunosuppressants is not appropriate and does not relate to the treatment of intussusception.

 

Option C. Anti-inflammatory drugs are not the primary treatment for intussusception, which is a mechanical obstruction and not merely an inflammatory process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception post-Rotavirus vaccination is a rare but serious condition where the bowel telescopes into itself due to potential lymphoid hyperplasia induced by the vaccine. Management necessitates an urgent referral to a pediatric surgeon for potential surgical intervention to prevent life-threatening complications.

 

Ref: OP Ghai Page No- 183-195.

choices.text: Severe allergic reaction- recommend immediate administration of epinephrine
Febrile seizure- recommend antipyretic therapy and observation
Localized pain and swelling at the injection site- recommend cold compresses and pain relief medication
Anaphylaxis- recommend referral to the emergency department for further management

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant, Krish, is presented to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of a high-pitched cough, runny nose, and a mild fever. Upon inquiry, the mother reveals that Krish received his pertussis vaccine two days ago. The physician considers the possibility of a vaccine-related adverse event. Which of the following is the most common side effect of the pertussis vaccine, and how should it be managed in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Localized pain and swelling at the injection site, recommend cold compresses and pain relief medication

 

Option C:

 

The most common side effects of the pertussis vaccine are minor and include localized pain, redness, and swelling at the injection site, as well as mild fever. These symptoms are typically self-limiting and can be managed with simple measures such as cold compresses to reduce swelling and over-the-counter pain relief medication to manage discomfort. The symptoms described by Krish's mother do not indicate a severe allergic reaction or anaphylaxis, which are much less common and would present with more severe systemic symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option. A severe allergic reaction would present immediately after vaccination and would be more acute and severe than the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Febrile seizures are a rare side effect of the pertussis vaccine and are associated with high fever, which is not the case here as the fever is described as mild.

 

Option D. Anaphylaxis is a very rare but serious reaction that would typically occur within minutes to hours after vaccination, presenting with signs such as difficulty breathing, hives, swelling of the face and throat, a rapid heartbeat, and severe weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Localized pain and swelling are the most common side effects of the pertussis vaccine, typically resolving within a few days. Management includes cold compresses and pain relief medication, with parental monitoring for any signs of infection at the injection site.

 

Ref: OP Ghai Page No- 183-195.

choices.text: A live vaccine is a vaccine that contains a killed virus, and it is safe for all children
A live vaccine is a vaccine that contains a weakened or attenuated virus, and it is safe for most children
A live vaccine is a vaccine that contains a live virus, and it is not recommended for any child
A live vaccine is a vaccine that contains both live and killed virus, and it is safe for most children, but not recommended for children with weakened immune systems

questions.text: A mother visits the pediatric clinic for her 2-year-old child's routine check-up. During the visit, she expresses concerns about the scheduled administration of a live vaccine. As the pediatrician, how would you explain what a live vaccine is, and what safety guidance would you provide regarding these vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A live vaccine is a vaccine that contains a weakened or attenuated virus, and it is safe for most children.

 

Option B:

 

Live vaccines use a weakened (attenuated) form of the germ that causes a disease. These vaccines are closely related to the natural infection that they help prevent and create a strong and long-lasting immune response. They are generally safe for most children; however, they are not recommended for children with certain health conditions, particularly those that affect the immune system, because the weakened virus may still cause disease in these individuals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This statement is incorrect as live vaccines do not contain a killed virus; that would be an inactivated vaccine.

 

Option C. This statement is misleading. Live vaccines do contain a live virus, but it is attenuated and safe for most children, not all.
