Option D. This statement is partially correct but is misleading in suggesting that live vaccines can contain both live and killed viruses. While live vaccines are safe for most children, they are indeed not recommended for children with weakened immune systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines, such as MMR, varicella, and rotavirus, are generally safe for most children but may not be suitable for those with certain medical conditions or compromised immune systems, who could face serious complications from vaccine-preventable diseases

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 739

questions.text: In the midst of a busy day at the outpatient department, a junior doctor opens a vial of the DPT vaccine. Following the Open Vial Policy, you remind her to document the time the vial was opened for potential reuse later on. To test her knowledge on the policy, you question her about which vaccine listed below does not follow the Open Vial Policy.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MMR

 

Explanation:

 

Open Vial Policy 2015

 

  • Applicable for Vaccines: OPV, DPT, Hepatitis B, DT/TT, Liquid Pentavalent, IPV
  • Not applicable for Vaccines: Measles/ MMR, BCG, JE, rotavirus
  • Opened vaccine vials can be used in subsequent session UP TO 4 WEEKS
  • Expiry date should not pass, VVM within usability limits, Cold chain maintenance
  • Vaccine vial septum not submerged in water or contaminated, Aseptic technique used to
  • withdraw doses
  • Record date and time of each vial opening
  • At end of session return all open vials to Cold chain:
    • Reusable open vials: DPT, DT, Hepatitis B, Pentavalent
    • Non-reusable open vials: Measles/MMR, BCG, JE (Destroy after 48 hours or Next session whichever earlier)
    • If any AEFI reported: Store all vials in Cold chain till completion of investigation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open Vial Policy is used for the multidosing vials for reuse within 4 weeks under proper cold chain maintenance and within the expiry date.

 

The vaccines following open vial policy are TT, OPV, DPT, Hep-B, Pentavalent and IPV.

 

Ref: OP Ghai Page No- 183-193.

choices.text: Dew drop on a rose petal

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to a pediatric outpatient department with a 3-day history of high fever, runny nose, red eyes, and small white spots inside the mouth. On examination, a red, blotchy rash is noted on the skin. The child's immunization history is incomplete. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is considered a pathognomonic sign of the suspected disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Koplik spots

 

Option A:

 

Koplik spots are seen in case of measles and it is the pathognomonic sign. The clinical features of measles include fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis and rash. These are bluish-gray spots on mucosa which appear before rash and are most commonly seen opposite of the lower 2nd molar.

 

(NOTE- This is in contrast with the location of opening of parotid duct- Stensons duct, which is exactly at upper 2nd molar)

 

The rash typically begins behind the ears (retroauricular).

 

Koplik spots can also appear in conjunctiva and vagina.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Nagayama spots: These are small, red papules found on the soft palate and uvula, typically seen in cases of Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum), caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), not measles.

 

Option C: Forchheimer spots: Petechiae on the soft palate, often associated with rubella (German measles), not the classic measles described in the scenario.

 

Option D: Dew drops on a rose petal seen in chickenpox (Varicella).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koplik spots are considered as a hallmark feature in diagnosing measles, especially in the context of the clinical presentation, which is remembered by 3 C 

  1. Ccough 

  2. Coryza and 

  3. Conjunctivitis 
     

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1542-1547.

questions.text: A 34-year-old mother brought her 2-month-old infant to your pediatric clinic, who reports that the baby developed a fever on Sunday, followed by the eruption of a distinctive rash on Friday. The mother is concerned and suspects that the rash might be related to her sister-in-law, who frequently kisses the child on the cheeks and playfully pinches and slaps him. Upon examination, the child presents with bright red erythema on both cheeks, giving a "slapped" appearance, without significant involvement of the nasal bridge and circumoral region. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slapped Cheek appearance

 

Option B:

 

Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped cheek syndrome, is a viral infection caused by the human parvovirus B19. It is most common in children but can affect people of all ages.

 

  • The first symptoms of Erythema infectiosum (The fifth disease) include fever, headache, and muscle aches.
  • Within a few days, a rash appears on the face, giving it a "slapped cheek" appearance. The rash may spread to the arms, legs, and trunk.
  • The rash is usually not itchy, but some people may experience joint pain and swelling, particularly in adults.
  • The rash may last for several weeks, but it usually goes away on its own without any complications.

 

Treatment: There is no specific treatment for Erythema infectiosum, as it is a viral infection (Parvovirus B19). Treatment is usually focused on relieving symptoms, such as fever and joint pain, with over-the-counter pain relievers and anti-inflammatory medications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Kissing disease: Also known as infectious mononucleosis, it is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). It typically presents with fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy, not primarily with a cheek rash.

 

Option C: Battered baby syndrome: This term refers to physical abuse of infants, leading to multiple injuries. The described scenario and rash do not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option D: Juvenile SLE: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) can affect children, but the classic malar rash associated with SLE spares the nasolabial folds, which is different from the described presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Slapped Cheek" appearance is characteristic of Parvovirus B19 infection, also known as erythema infectiosum or Fifth disease; commonly affects children and presents with a distinctive facial rash that resembles the appearance as if the cheeks have been slapped. The rash can subsequently spread to the body, forming a lacy pattern.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1570-1588

questions.text: Match the following characteristic findings along with their disease causative agent:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A3 B4 C1 D2

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Nodular rash with indentation: This description is characteristic of poxvirus infections, such as chickenpox (varicella) and smallpox, where the lesions are often described as "dewdrop on a rose petal" for chickenpox, and with deep indentations for smallpox.

 

Option B: Koplik spots: These are small, white, grain-like spots found on the buccal mucosa opposite the first and second molars, and are pathognomonic for measles (Rubeola).

 

Option C: Forchheimer spots: These are pinpoint red spots seen on the soft palate, often associated with German measles (Rubella).

 

Option D: Pastia's lines: These are linear petechial rash found in the creases of the body, particularly in the antecubital fossa, and are associated with scarlet fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 6733

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 8-year-old child with complaints of fever, sore throat, and a rash. On asking history, the child explains that the rash started on the chest and then spread to the rest of the body. On examination the rash consisted of small, red bumps that felt like sandpaper. The child also complains of a headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, the tongue is found to be red and swollen, the image is given below.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scarlet fever

 

Option C:

 

The clinical features described in the case are typical of scarlet fever.

  • Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection caused by group A Streptococcus bacteria that produces a toxin causing the characteristic rash and other symptoms.

  • The symptoms typically start with a sore throat, fever, and a bright red tongue (strawberry tongue). After a few days, a rash develops on the chest and then spreads to the rest of the body.

  • The rash consists of small, red bumps that feel like sandpaper and may itch.

  • The child may also complain of a headache, nausea, and vomiting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Streptococcal pharyngitis, is a bacterial infection of the throat caused by group A streptococcus bacteria. It can cause a sore throat, fever, and other symptoms, but is not typically associated with a rash.

 

Option B: Rocky Mountain spotted fever, is a bacterial infection transmitted by ticks. It can cause fever, headache, and a characteristic spotted rash, but is not typically associated with a sore throat or the rash described in the case.

 

Option D: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, is a bacterial infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus that produces a toxin causing the skin to blister and peel. It typically presents with fever, a red, scalded-looking rash, and other symptoms, but is not typically associated with a sore throat or the rash described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

The clinical presentation of fever, sore throat, rash starting on the chest and spreading, rash texture described as sandpaper-like, along with headache, nausea, vomiting, and a red, swollen tongue (often referred to as "strawberry tongue")is indicative of Scarlet fever.

 

Scarlet fever is a condition that arises as a result of an infection with group A Streptococcus, which produces a toxin leading to the characteristic rash.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-1328

questions.text: Match the following Inclusion bodies and their infectious disease:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A2 B4 C3 D1

 

Option A: Henderson Patterson Bodies (A2): These inclusion bodies are characteristic of Molluscum Contagiosum. They are found within the cytoplasm of infected epithelial cells and are a diagnostic feature of the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Cowdry Type A (B4): Cowdry Type A inclusion bodies are typically associated with Herpes Simplex Virus infections. They are eosinophilic, intranuclear inclusions found in infected cells.

 

Option C: Cowdry Type B (C3): Though Cowdry Type B inclusions are specifically linked to Polio Virus.

 

Option D: Guarnieri Bodies (D1): Guarnieri bodies are pathognomonic of Small Pox infection caused by the Variola virus. They are eosinophilic or basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the cytoplasm of infected cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought in by their mother due to fever and irritability. Notably, the child has a smaller head circumference than expected for their age. The mother recalls experiencing a mild, flu-like illness during her pregnancy. The histopathology examination of the same virus reveals the following cells. Given this history, clinical presentation and histopathology findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infection

 

Option B:

 

Given histopathology image shows the typical owl’s eye appearance of CMV which are actually basophilic intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies due to the cytopathic effect of the virus.

 

(NOTE- This is in contrast with the owl’s eye appearance seen in the Reed-Sternberg cells of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, which are actually eosinophilic intranuclear inclusion bodies with a background of inflammatory cells.)

 

CMV is a common viral infection that can be transmitted from a mother to her foetus during pregnancy.

 

Infants with congenital CMV infection may present with a range of symptoms, including fever, irritability, hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen)

 

The mother's history of a mild flu-like illness during pregnancy is a risk factor for acquiring CMV.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Congenital Rubella Syndrome: While congenital rubella can cause microcephaly, it is typically associated with additional features such as cataracts, heart defects, and hearing loss.

 

Option C: Congenital Syphilis: Congenital syphilis can lead to a variety of symptoms, including rash, hepatosplenomegaly, and bone abnormalities, but microcephaly is not as characteristic as in congenital CMV.

 

Option D: Congenital Toxoplasmosis: This condition can also cause microcephaly, but the mother's flu-like illness is more suggestive of a viral etiology like CMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of microcephaly, fever, irritability, and the mother's history of a mild flu-like illness during pregnancy is suggestive of Congenital CMV Infection.

 

Ref: OP Ghai, Page No-264-265.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric outpatient department in a tertiary care hospital in India by his mother, who is concerned that her son has never passed urine from the tip of his penis. The child has otherwise been healthy with no significant medical history. On physical examination, the urethral orifice is not located at the usual position at the tip of the penis. The rest of the genital examination shows normal testicular descent and no other abnormalities.

Which among the following is the most common congenital urethral anomaly?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypospadias

 

Option D:

 

Hypospadias is a congenital condition where the urethral opening is located on the underside of the penis rather than at the tip. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the penis, affecting approximately 1 in every 250 male births.

 

The characteristic features: The external meatus opens on the underside of the penis anywhere from just short of the normal site as far back as the perineum, while the ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed (the ‘hooded prepuce’) and there is usually a ventral deformity of the erect penis.

 

Management typically involves surgical repair to extend the urethral opening to the tip of the penis, usually performed before the child reaches 18 months of age to facilitate normal urination and, in the future, sexual function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epispadias: This is a less common condition where the urethral opening is on the upper surface of the penis. It often presents with more severe anatomical anomalies and can be associated with bladder exstrophy.

 

Option B. Urethral stenosis: This involves a narrowing of the urethra, which can lead to difficulty urinating but does not involve abnormal placement of the urethral opening.

 

Option C. Bladder exstrophy: A rare congenital condition where the bladder and associated structures are exposed outside the abdomen. It is usually noticeable immediately after birth due to the visible bladder tissue and associated abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypospadias is the most common congenital urethral anomaly and management involves surgical repair.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No- 1063.

choices.text: Posterior urethral valve
Stricture of urethra

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-month-old male child with complaints of dribbling of urine and recurrent urinary tract infections. During her prenatal visits, the doctor mentioned abnormal radiographic findings, but she forgot about it due to the long gap since her last pregnancy. Upon reviewing her old medical file, you find the following ultrasound (USG) image. Based on the clinical features and the image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior urethral valve.

 

Option B:

 

The image is suggestive of a keyhole appearance, which is seen in the case of Posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valve causes over distention of bladder with urine stagnation which leads to UTI and due to overdistention there occurs overflow dribbling in some cases.

 

  • PUV occurs in male child
  • Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound,
  • USG demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder giving a key hole appearance.
  • Investigation will involve a voiding cystourethrogram, with the dilatation of the urethra above the valves demonstrable on a voiding cystourethrogram/ micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).
  • The bladder is hypertrophied and often shows diverticula.
  • Typically, there is vesicoureteric reflux into dilated upper tracts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ureterocele: While ureterocele is a congenital anomaly involving the distal ureter, it typically presents with a cystic dilatation at the ureteric orifice within the bladder, rather than causing obstruction in the urethra. There will be an adder head or Cobra head appearance on IVP.

 

Option C. Urethral stricture: Urethral stricture refers to narrowing of the urethra due to scar tissue or inflammation. While it can cause urinary flow obstruction, it typically presents differently and is less common in infants.

 

Option D. Neurogenic bladder: Neurogenic bladder dysfunction is often associated with conditions affecting the central or peripheral nervous system, leading to abnormal bladder function. While it can cause urinary symptoms, the clinical presentation and imaging findings in this case are more suggestive of posterior urethral valves. This will show the Christmas tree appearance not the keyhole appearance.

 

Educational objective:

 

The clinical presentation of dribbling of urine and recurrent urinary tract infections in a male child, along with the history of prenatal radiographic findings suggestive of an abnormality, raises suspicion for posterior urethral valves (PUV).

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 555 Page No- From 10988.

choices.text: Posterior urethral Valve

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old girl child with complaints of fever and crying during micturition. On examination, the left side loin of the child has a mass which resolves after urination. On routine urine analysis, UTI was suspected. On asking history, the mother admits to multiple episodes of UTI. USG shows hydronephrosis and the following appearance. What is the diagnosis based on the clinical features and radiological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureterocele

 

Option C:

 

A girl having recurrent UTI, hydronephrosis and filling defect in bladder are typical findings of ureterocele. Ureterocele is basically a dilatation of the distal intramural part of ureter which on MCU appears as a filling defect and as a cobra head appearance or adder head appearance on IVP.

 

Vesicoureteric reflux will show up as a reflux of dye into ureter and dilated tortuous ureter.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vesicoureteric reflux: Vesicoureteric reflux involves the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters, often leading to recurrent UTIs and, in severe cases, hydronephrosis. However, it typically does not present with a mass in the loin that resolves after urination.

 

Option B. Hydronephrosis: Hydronephrosis refers to the dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to obstruction of urinary flow. While it can be associated with ureterocele, it is not the primary diagnosis in this case.

 

Option D. Posterior urethral valve: Posterior urethral valve is a condition affecting male infants, leading to obstructive uropathy and features such as dribbling of urine, recurrent UTIs, and characteristic imaging findings. It is less common in female children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureterocele is a congenital abnormality where the distal end of the ureter balloons within the bladder, leading to obstructive uropathy. This can result in hydronephrosis and recurrent UTIs. The characteristic ultrasound (USG) appearance often shows a cystic dilatation at the ureteric orifice within the bladder.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 10987

choices.text: It is due to the mutation in the gene responsible for collagen
Superotemporal dislocation of lens can be seen
Child will present with features of tall stature and joint hypermobility
Can be associated with Cardiac abnormalities

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric department by her mother, who is concerned about the child's delayed developmental milestones, hypermobility, and frequent dislocations of her shoulders and knees. Upon examination, the pediatrician also notes decreased visual acuity and suspects a condition related to a protein defect with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Which of the following statements about the suspected disease is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is due to the mutation in the gene responsible for Collagen

 

Option A:

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical history given is the Marfan’s syndrome.

 

Marfan's syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting the connective tissue, resulting from mutations in the FBN1 (fibrillin-1) gene. Fibrillin-1 is a glycoprotein that is essential for the formation of elastic fibres found in connective tissue. It primarily affects the skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular systems.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Superotemporal dislocation of the lens: This is true for Marfan syndrome. Lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) is a common ocular manifestation, with the lens typically dislocating in a superotemporal direction.  Other Ocular manifestations can include near-sightedness and retinal detachment.

 

Option C: Tall stature and joint hypermobility: Patients with Marfan syndrome often present with a tall stature, long limbs, and joint hypermobility, which are characteristic features of the condition. May include a curved spine, and chest deformities such as pectus excavatum. Patients may also experience joint hypermobility.

 

Option D: Cardiac abnormalities: Marfan syndrome can be associated with various cardiac issues, most notably aortic dilatation and dissection (aortic aneurysms), which are significant causes of morbidity and mortality in affected individuals.

Early diagnosis and careful monitoring are crucial to managing the condition and preventing severe complications. Treatment options focus on symptom management and surgical interventions if necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan syndrome, which is indeed due to a mutation in the FBN1 gene responsible for the production of fibrillin-1, not collagen.

 

Ref- Nelson 20th Edition, Page No- 618-619

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl named Rohini is brought to the clinic by her father due to a history of frequent falls. Initial X-rays reveal multiple fractures at various stages of healing, accompanied by numerous bruises on her skin. Given the suspicious nature of the injuries, child abuse is considered. However, upon a thorough examination, Rohini is found to have short stature, blue sclera, and deformities in her long bones and spine, leading to a re-evaluation of the initial suspicion towards a genetic disorder involving collagen. Based on Rohini's clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis, and which gene is implicated in her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis imperfecta and COL1A1

 

Option C:

 

The diagnosis based on the Rohini’s history is Osteogenesis imperfecta and it is Autosomal Dominant in nature. The Clinical features include:

 

  • Multiple fractures: recurrent fractures, which can occur with minimal or no trauma causing deformities or shortening of limbs.
  • Blue sclera: It’s due to the underlying connective tissue abnormalities.
  • Dental problems: Brittle teeth that break easily or wear down quickly.
  • Hearing loss
  • Skeletal deformities: scoliosis (curvature of the spine), kyphosis (hunchback), or pectus excavatum (sunken chest).
  • Short stature: due to the impact of skeletal abnormalities on bone growth.
  • Easy bruising: Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause easy bruising or bleeding, particularly in people with severe forms of the condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Osteogenesis imperfecta and COL4A1: This option is incorrect because OI is typically associated with mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, not COL4A1.

 

Option B: Marfan’s syndrome and COL1A1: Marfan syndrome is a disorder that affects connective tissue, characterized by tall stature, long limbs, and cardiovascular abnormalities, among others. It is most commonly caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, not COL1A1, and does not typically result in fractures or blue sclera as seen in OI.

 

Option D: Marfan’s syndrome and COL4A1: Marfan syndrome is not associated with mutations in the COL4A1 gene. COL4A1 mutations are linked to different conditions, such as certain types of cerebral small vessel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blue sclera, bone deformities, short stature, and a history of multiple fractures, are classic for Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI), a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, which encode type I collagen, a crucial component of bone, skin, and other connective tissues.

 

Ref- Nelson 20th Edition, Page No-3423.
